It is the seventh track off his first album, ''[[Empty Sky]]''. ==Musical structure== It opens with a bluesy minor-key electric piano, before going into a somewhat quiet, relaxed main riff. A rhythm section plays a steady beat, but is more silent compared to other tracks. It changes between major and minor keys, making the music very confusing. ==Lyrical meaning== Taupin wrote the song as a tribute to [[The Scaffold]], a group of comedians, musicians and poets from [[Liverpool]]. One of the members were [[Mike McGear]], [[Paul McCartney]]'s baby brother. The song praises them in the chorus, but the verses are very cryptic and mysterious. One might think that the influence could have been Bob Dylan; the first two verses go: "''In Orient where wise I was
''To please the way I live
''Come give the beggar chance at hand
''His life is on his lip ''Three score a thousand times
''Were once in Amazon
''Where Eldorado holds the key
''No keeper holds my hand''" John appeared on some of The Scaffold's album as a musician. Both John and Taupin were big fans. ==Performances== Along with the previous song on the album, "[[Sails (song)|Sails]]", this was also performed on John's first solo radio performance. Since then, it hasn't been played in any format. ==Personnel== *Elton John - [[electric piano]], vocals *[[Caleb Quaye]] - [[Acoustic guitar|guitar]] *Tony Murray - [[Bass guitar|bass]] *Roger Pope - [[Drum kit|drums]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Scaffold}} [[Category:1969 songs]] [[Category:Elton John songs]] [[Category:Psychedelic songs]] [[Category:Songs with lyrics by Bernie Taupin]] [[Category:Songs with music by Elton John]] [[it:The Scaffold]]
